==Stadium==
{{Main article|Stamford Bridge (stadium)}}
[[File:Stamford Bridge - West Stand.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], West Stand]]
Chelsea have only had one home ground, Stamford Bridge, where they have played since the team's foundation. It was officially opened on 28 April 1877 and for the first 28 years of its existence it was used almost exclusively by the [[London Athletic Club]] as an arena for athletics meetings and not at all for football. In 1904 the ground was acquired by businessman [[Gus Mears]] and his brother [[Joseph Mears|Joseph]], who had also purchased nearby land (formerly a large market garden) with the aim of staging football matches on the now 12.5 acre (51,000 m²) site.<ref name="stadium"/> Stamford Bridge was designed for the Mears family by the noted football architect [[Archibald Leitch]], who had also designed [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox]], [[Craven Cottage]] and [[Hampden Park]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=69–71}}</ref> Most football clubs were founded first, and then sought grounds in which to play, but Chelsea were founded for Stamford Bridge.

Starting with an open bowl-like design and one covered terrace, Stamford Bridge had an original capacity of around 100,000.<ref name="stadium"/> The early 1930s saw the construction of a terrace on the southern part of the ground with a roof that covered around one fifth of the stand. It eventually became known as the "Shed End", the home of Chelsea's most loyal and vocal supporters, particularly during the 1960s, 70s and 80s. The exact origins of the name are unclear, but the fact that the roof looked like a corrugated iron shed roof played a part.<ref name="stadium">{{cite web
 |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/StadiumHistory/0,,10268,00.html
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512170633/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/StadiumHistory/0%2C%2C10268%2C00.html
 |archivedate=12 May 2012
 |title=Stadium History – Introduction
 |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC
 |accessdate=20 May 2012
 |deadurl=yes
 |df=dmy
}}</ref>

In the early 1970s, the club's owners announced a modernisation of Stamford Bridge with plans for a state-of-the-art 50,000 all-seater stadium.<ref name="stadium"/> Work began on the East Stand in 1972 but the project was beset with problems and was never completed; the cost brought the club close to bankruptcy, culminating in the [[Fee simple|freehold]] being sold to property developers. Following a long legal battle, it was not until the mid-1990s that Chelsea's future at the stadium was secured and renovation work resumed.<ref name="stadium"/> The north, west and southern parts of the ground were converted into all-seater stands and moved closer to the pitch, a process completed by 2001.

When Stamford Bridge was redeveloped in the [[Ken Bates|Bates]] era many additional features were added to the complex including two hotels, apartments, bars, restaurants, the Chelsea Megastore, and an interactive visitor attraction called Chelsea World of Sport. The intention was that these facilities would provide extra revenue to support the football side of the business, but they were less successful than hoped and before the Abramovich takeover in 2003 the debt taken on to finance them was a major burden on the club. Soon after the takeover a decision was taken to drop the "Chelsea Village" brand and refocus on Chelsea as a football club. However, the stadium is sometimes still referred to as part of ''"Chelsea Village"'' or ''"The Village"''.
[[File:Chelsea-ilkmac.jpg|left|frame|Chelsea ''vs.'' [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] at Stamford Bridge on 23 September 1905; Chelsea won 1–0.]]
The Stamford Bridge [[Freehold (law)|freehold]], the [[Association football pitch|pitch]], the turnstiles and Chelsea's [[naming rights]] are now owned by [[Chelsea Pitch Owners]], a non-profit organisation in which fans are the shareholders. The CPO was created to ensure the stadium could never again be sold to developers. As a condition for using the Chelsea FC name, the club has to play its first team matches at Stamford Bridge, which means that if the club moves to a new stadium, they may have to change their name.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=91–92}}</ref>
Chelsea's [[Cobham Training Centre|training ground]] is located in [[Cobham, Surrey]]. Chelsea moved to Cobham in 2004. Their previous training ground in [[Harlington, London|Harlington]] was taken over by [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|QPR]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite news |title=QPR take over Chelsea training ground |first=Wayne |last=Veysey |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/qpr-take-over-chelsea-training-ground-7179619.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121025213214/http://www.standard.co.uk/sport/qpr-take-over-chelsea-training-ground-7179619.html |archivedate=25 October 2012 |work=London Evening Standard |date=24 May 2005 |accessdate=24 June 2009 }}</ref> The new training facilities in Cobham were completed in 2007.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea's new training ground for the future |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/london/content/articles/2007/07/05/chelsea_ground_feature.shtml |publisher=BBC London |date=5 July 2007 |accessdate=24 June 2009 }}</ref>

Stamford Bridge has been used for a variety of other sporting events since 1905. ==Crest and colours==

===Crest===

Chelsea have had four main [[crest (sports)|crests]], which all underwent minor variations. The first, adopted when the club was founded, was the image of a [[Chelsea pensioner]], the army veterans who reside at the nearby [[Royal Hospital Chelsea]]. This contributed to the club's original "pensioner" nickname, and remained for the next half-century, though it never appeared on the shirts. When [[Ted Drake]] became Chelsea manager in 1952, he began to modernise the club. Believing the Chelsea pensioner crest to be old-fashioned, he insisted that it be replaced.<ref name="crest">{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=42}}</ref> A stop-gap badge which comprised the initials C.F.C. was adopted for a year. In 1953, the club crest was changed to an upright blue lion looking backwards and holding a [[crosier|staff]]. It was based on elements in the [[coat of arms]] of the [[Metropolitan Borough of Chelsea]]<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.civicheraldry.co.uk/lcc.html#chelsea%20bc
|title=Chelsea Metropolitan Borough Council
|work=Civic Heraldry of England and Wales
|accessdate=21 January 2007}}</ref> with the "lion rampant regardant" taken from the arms of then club president [[William Cadogan, 7th Earl Cadogan|Viscount Chelsea]] and the staff from the [[Westminster Abbey|Abbots of Westminster]], former Lords of the Manor of Chelsea. It also featured three red roses, to represent England, and two footballs.<ref name="crest"/> This was the first Chelsea crest to appear on the shirts, in the early 1960s.

In 1986, with [[Ken Bates]] now owner of the club, Chelsea's crest was changed again as part of another attempt to modernise and because the old rampant lion badge could not be trademarked.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/club-history/1980.html
|title=1980s Summary
|publisher=Chelsea FC
|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> The new badge featured a more naturalistic non-heraldic lion, in white and not blue, standing over the C.F.C. initials. This lasted for the next 19 years, with some modifications such as the use of different colours, including red from 1987 to 1995, and yellow from 1995 until 1999, before the white returned.<ref name="HFK">{{cite web|title=Historical Kits – Chelsea
|url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea.htm
|first=Dave
|last=Moor
|publisher=Historical Kits
|accessdate=28 September 2011}}</ref> With the new ownership of [[Roman Abramovich]], and the club's centenary approaching, combined with demands from fans for the popular 1950s badge to be restored, it was decided that the crest should be changed again in 2005. The new crest was officially adopted for the start of the [[2005–06 in English football|2005–06]] season and marked a return to the older design, used from 1953 to 1986, featuring a blue heraldic lion holding a staff. For the centenary season this was accompanied by the words '100 YEARS' and 'CENTENARY 2005–2006' on the top and bottom of the crest respectively.<ref name="new crest"/>

===Colours===

Chelsea have always worn blue shirts, although they originally used the paler [[eton blue]], which was taken from the racing colours of then club president, [[Earl Cadogan]], and was worn with white shorts and dark blue or black socks.<ref>{{cite web
 |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea.htm
 |title=Chelsea – Historical Football Kits
 |work=Historical Kits
 |accessdate=26 June 2012
 }}</ref> The light blue shirts were replaced by a royal blue version in around 1912.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |title=Chelsea Football Club: The Official History in Pictures|year=2006|isbn=978-0-7553-1467-6}} p. 212</ref> In the 1960s Chelsea manager [[Tommy Docherty]] changed the kit again, switching to blue shorts (which have remained ever since) and white socks, believing it made the club's colours more modern and distinctive, since no other major side used that combination; this kit was first worn during the 1964–65 season.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mears |first=Brian |title=Chelsea: Football Under the Blue Flag|publisher=Mainstream Sport|year=2002|isbn=978-1-84018-658-1 |page=42 }}</ref> Since then Chelsea have always worn white socks with their home kit apart from a short spell from 1985 to 1992, when blue socks were reintroduced.

Chelsea's away colours are usually all yellow or all white with blue trim. More recently, the club have had a number of black or dark blue away kits which alternate every year.<ref name="change kits">{{cite web
 |url=http://www.historicalkits.co.uk/Chelsea/Chelsea-change-kits.html
 |title=Chelsea Change Kits
 |work=Historical Kits
 |accessdate=7 December 2015
 }}</ref> As with most teams, they have also had some more unusual ones. At Docherty's behest, in the 1966 FA Cup semi-final they wore blue and black stripes, based on [[Inter Milan]]'s kit.<ref>{{cite book |last=Mears|first=Brian |title=Chelsea: Football Under the Blue Flag|publisher=|year=2002|page=58 }}</ref> In the mid-1970s, the away strip was a red, white and green kit inspired by the [[Golden Team|Hungarian national side]] of the 1950s.<ref>{{cite book |last=Batty |first=Clive|title=Kings of the King's Road: The Great Chelsea Team of the 60s & 70s|publisher=Vision Sports Publishing|year=2007|isbn=978-1-905326-22-8 |page=244}}</ref> Other memorable away kits include an all jade strip worn from 1986–89, red and white diamonds from 1990–92, graphite and tangerine from 1994–96, and luminous yellow from 2007–08.<ref name="change kits"/> The graphite and tangerine strip often appears in lists of the worst football kits ever.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2007/aug/12/sport.obsmagspecial9|title=Eyes wide shut|work=The Observer|date=12 August 2007|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref>

==Support==
[[File:Chelsea defend corner.jpg|thumb|250px|Chelsea fans at a match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], on 11 March 2006]]
Chelsea are among the most widely supported football clubs in the world.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/511644/Chelsea-are-a-more-universally-loved-club-Blues-chief-lauds-400million-fan-base |title=Chelsea are a more universally loved club! Blues chief lauds 400million fan base |last=Anderson |first=Jamie |work=Daily Express |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://talksport.com/magazine/big-picture/2011-10-13/worlds-most-popular-football-club-revealed-man-united-liverpool-arsenal-barca-real-or-chelsea|title=The world's most popular football club revealed: Man United, Liverpool F.C., Arsenal F.C., Barca, Real or Chelsea?|work=talkSPORT|date=2011-10-13}}</ref> They have the sixth highest average all-time attendance in [[Football in England|English football]]<ref name="All-time attendance"/> and regularly attract over 40,000 fans to Stamford Bridge; they were the seventh best-supported [[Premier League]] team in the 2013–14 season, with an average gate of 41,572.<ref name="14/15 attendances"/> Chelsea's traditional fanbase comes from all over the [[Greater London]] area including working-class parts such as [[Hammersmith]] and [[Battersea]], wealthier areas like Chelsea and [[Kensington]], and from the [[home counties]]. There are also numerous official supporters clubs in the United Kingdom and all over the world.<ref>{{cite web
|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/supporters-clubs
|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140323222258/http://www.chelseafc.com/supporters-clubs
|archivedate=23 March 2014
|title=Supporters Clubs Map
|work=chelseafc.com
|accessdate=23 March 2014}}</ref> Between 2007 and 2012, Chelsea were ranked fourth worldwide in annual replica kit sales, with an average of 910,000.<ref>{{cite news |title=EXCLUSIVE: Manchester United and Real Madrid top global shirt sale charts |url=http://www.sportingintelligence.com/2012/10/08/exclusive-manchester-united-and-real-madrid-top-global-shirt-sale-charts-081001/ |work=Sporting Intelligence|date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=8 October 2012}}</ref> Chelsea's official Twitter account has 9.8 million followers as of September 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://folos.im/|title=League Table of Twitter Followers|work=Folos|accessdate=4 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208081452/http://folos.im/|archive-date=8 December 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

At matches, Chelsea fans sing [[football chants|chants]] such as "[[Carefree (chant)|Carefree]]" (to the tune of "[[Lord of the Dance (hymn)|Lord of the Dance]]", whose lyrics were probably written by supporter Mick Greenaway<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=150}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://fanchants.com/football-songs/chelsea-chants/carefree/ |title="Carefree" audio sample |publisher=Fanchants.com |accessdate=3 September 2011}}</ref>), "Ten Men Went to Mow", "We All Follow the Chelsea" (to the tune of "[[Land of Hope and Glory]]"), "Zigga Zagga", and the celebratory "Celery", with the latter often resulting in fans ritually throwing celery. The vegetable was banned inside Stamford Bridge after an incident involving [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] midfielder [[Cesc Fàbregas]] at the [[2007 Football League Cup Final|2007 League Cup Final]].<ref>{{cite news
|date=17 April 2002
|url=http://football.guardian.co.uk/News_Story/0,1563,685859,00.html
|title=Fans sent spinning after tossing salad |work=The Guardian
|accessdate=1 January 2007
|first=Scott |last=Murray}}</ref>
During the 1970s and 1980s in particular, Chelsea supporters were associated with [[Football (soccer) hooliganism|football hooliganism]]. The club's "[[Football hooliganism|football firm]]", originally known as the Chelsea Shed Boys, and subsequently as the [[Chelsea Headhunters]], were nationally notorious for football violence, alongside hooligan firms from other clubs such as [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]]'s [[Inter City Firm]] and [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]'s [[Millwall Bushwackers|Bushwackers]], before, during and after matches.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/programmes/hooligans/1962503.stm
|title=Making a new start
|publisher=BBC News
|accessdate=21 January 2007
|date=2 May 2002}}</ref> The increase of hooligan incidents in the 1980s led chairman Ken Bates to propose erecting an electric fence to deter them from invading the pitch, a proposal that the [[Greater London Council]] rejected.<ref>{{cite news
|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/3037508.stm
|title=Bates: Chelsea's driving force
|publisher=BBC Sport
|accessdate=21 January 2007 |date=2 July 2003}}</ref>

Since the 1990s, there has been a marked decline in crowd trouble at matches, as a result of stricter policing, [[Closed-circuit television|CCTV]] in grounds and the advent of [[All-seater stadium|all-seater stadia]].<ref>{{cite news |date=2 June 1998 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/special_report/1998/hooligans/60146.stm |title=Soccer hooliganism: Made in England, but big abroad |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=1 January 2007}}</ref> In 2007, the club launched the [[Back to the Shed campaign|'Back to the Shed' campaign]] to improve the atmosphere at home matches, with notable success. According to [[Home Office]] statistics, 126 Chelsea fans were arrested for football-related offences during the [[2009–10 in English football|2009–10]] season, the third highest in the division, and 27 [[banning order]]s were issued, the fifth-highest in the division.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/publications/crime/football-arrests-banning-orders/fbo-2009-10?view=Binary |title=Statistics on football-related arrests and banning orders |accessdate=14 May 2011 |date=November 2010 |publisher=Home Office |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317054025/http://www.homeoffice.gov.uk/publications/crime/football-arrests-banning-orders/fbo-2009-10?view=Binary |archivedate=17 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

===Rivalries===
{{Main article|West London derby|Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|Chelsea F.C.–Tottenham Hotspur F.C. rivalry|Chelsea F.C.–Leeds United F.C. rivalry}}
Chelsea have long-standing rivalries with North London clubs [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=312–318}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/apr/22/a-brief-history-of-the-arsenal-chelsea-rivalry-and-why-it-matters|title=A brief history of the Arsenal-Chelsea rivalry and why it matters|work=The Guardian|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=7 December 2015}}</ref> A [[Chelsea F.C.–Leeds United F.C. rivalry|strong rivalry]] with [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] dates back to several heated and controversial matches in the 1960s and 1970s, particularly the [[1970 FA Cup Final]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=321–325}}</ref> More recently a rivalry with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] has grown following repeated clashes in cup competitions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.talksport.co.uk/magazine/features/2011-05-19/peterborough-v-mk-dons-liverpool-v-chelsea-stoke-v-cardiff-six-best-modern-football-rivalries|title=Six very modern football rivalries|work=TalkSport|accessdate=23 May 2011|date=19 May 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2015/oct/29/chelsea-liverpool-field-notes-rivalry|title=A brief guide to Chelsea's rivalry with Liverpool|work=The Guardian|date=29 October 2015|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref> Chelsea's fellow [[West London derby|West London]] sides [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]], [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] and [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] are generally not considered major rivals, as matches have only taken place intermittently due to the clubs often being in separate divisions.<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=311}}</ref>

A 2004 survey by Planetfootball.com found that Chelsea fans consider their main rivalries to be with (in descending order): [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], Tottenham Hotspur and [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. In the same survey, fans of Arsenal, Fulham, Leeds United, QPR, Tottenham, and West Ham United named Chelsea as one of their three main rivals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefootballnetwork.net/main/s120/st44186.htm|title=Football Rivalries: The Complete Results|publisher=Planetfootball.com|accessdate=2 January 2007}}</ref> In a 2008 poll conducted by the [[Football Fans Census]], Chelsea fans named Liverpool, Arsenal and Manchester United as their most disliked clubs. In the same survey, "Chelsea" was the top answer to the question "Which other English club do you dislike the most?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballfanscensus.com/londonfootballreport08.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140301030022/http://www.footballfanscensus.com/londonfootballreport08.pdf|archivedate=1 March 2014|title=The London Football Report 2008|publisher=Football Fans Census|accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref>

A 2012 survey, conducted among 1200 supporters of the top four league divisions across the country, found that many clubs’ main rivals had changed since 2003 and reported that Chelsea fans consider Tottenham to be their main rival, above Arsenal and Manchester United.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedaisycutter.co.uk/2012/09/football-rivalries-the-survey/|date=14 September 2012|title=Football Rivalries: The Survey|publisher=''The Daisy Cutter''|accessdate=22 May 2018}}</ref>

==Records==
{{details|List of Chelsea F.C. records and statistics}}
[[File:Frank Lampard'13-14.JPG|thumb|200px|[[Frank Lampard]] is Chelsea's all-time highest goalscorer.]]
Chelsea's highest appearance-maker is ex-captain [[Ron Harris (footballer)|Ron Harris]], who played in 795 competitive games for the club between 1961 and 1980.<ref name="stats">For the appearance and goalscoring records of all Chelsea players, see {{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |pages=399–410 }}</ref> The record for a Chelsea goalkeeper is held by Harris's contemporary, [[Peter Bonetti]], who made 729 appearances (1959–79). With 103 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] (101 while at the club), [[Frank Lampard]] of England is Chelsea's most capped international player.

Frank Lampard is Chelsea's all-time top goalscorer, with 211 goals in 648 games (2001–2014);<ref name="stats"/> he passed [[Bobby Tambling]]'s longstanding record of 202 in May 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22589526 |title=Chelsea's Frank Lampard given golden boot by Bobby Tambling |publisher=BBC |date=19 May 2013 |accessdate=7 September 2013 }}</ref> Seven other players have also scored over 100 goals for Chelsea: [[George Hilsdon]] (1906–12), [[George Mills (footballer)|George Mills]] (1929–39), [[Roy Bentley]] (1948–56), [[Jimmy Greaves]] (1957–61), [[Peter Osgood]] (1964–74 and 1978–79), [[Kerry Dixon]] (1983–92) and [[Didier Drogba]] (2004–12 and 2014–2015). Greaves holds the record for the most goals scored in one season (43 in 1960–61).<ref>{{cite web|title=Chelsea Legends|url=http://chelseazone.wordpress.com/chelsea-legends/|publisher=Chelsea News|accessdate=11 August 2014|date=2009-02-17}}</ref>

Chelsea's biggest winning scoreline in a competitive match is 13–0, achieved against [[Jeunesse Hautcharage]] in the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|Cup Winners' Cup]] in 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2465594|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140423225144/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2465594|dead-url=yes|archive-date=23 April 2014|title=Words on Winning: 21–0|website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 }}</ref> The club's biggest top-flight win was an 8–0 victory against [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] in 2010, which was matched in 2012 against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/matchday-live/match/47531|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140605231009/http://www.chelseafc.com/matchday-live/match/47531|archivedate=5 June 2014|title=Chelsea v Wigan match report |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 }}</ref> Chelsea's biggest loss was an 8–1 reverse against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] in 1953.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/teamsandplayers/teams/club=52914/profile/index.html|title=Chelsea FC|website=UEFA.com|publisher=Union of European Football Associations|accessdate=15 January 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/chelsea-article/article/3489606/title/ask-statman-37 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121213128/http://www.chelseafc.com/chelsea-article/article/3489606/title/ask-statman-37 |archivedate=21 November 2013|title=Ask Statsman 37|first=Paul|last=Dutton|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> Officially, Chelsea's highest home attendance is 82,905 for a [[Football League First Division|First Division]] match against Arsenal on 12 October 1935. However, an estimated crowd of over 100,000 attended a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] against Soviet team [[FC Dynamo Moscow|Dynamo Moscow]] on 13 November 1945.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1800268 |title=Team History – 1940s |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713083616/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/TeamHistory/0%2C%2C10268~1800268%2C00.html |archivedate=13 July 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Brian Viner: Diamond days of side who brought touch of glamour to post-war Britain |first=Brian |last=Viner |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/brian-viner-diamond-days-of-side-who-brought-touch-of-glamour-to-postwar-britain-6143279.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302032913/http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/brian-viner-diamond-days-of-side-who-brought-touch-of-glamour-to-postwar-britain-6143279.html |archivedate=2 March 2014 |work=The Independent |publisher=Independent Print Limited |date=29 October 2005 |accessdate=20 May 2012}}</ref> The modernisation of Stamford Bridge during the 1990s and the introduction of all-seater stands mean that neither record will be broken for the foreseeable future. The current legal capacity of Stamford Bridge is 41,663.<ref name="capacity"/> Every starting player in Chelsea's 57 games of the 2013–14 season was a full international – a new club record.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/08/pre-match-briefing--burnley-v-chelsea.html|title=Pre-Match Briefing: Burnley v Chelsea – part one|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>

[[File:Fernando Torres 03 Chelsea vs AS-Roma 10AUG2013.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Chelsea signed [[Fernando Torres]] for £50 million, then the record for a purchase by a British club.]]
Chelsea hold the English record for the fewest goals conceded during a league season (15), the highest number of clean sheets overall in a Premier League season (25) (both set during the [[2004–05 FA Premier League|2004–05 season]]),<ref name="records">{{cite news |date=13 May 2005|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/4545045.stm|title=Mourinho proud of battling finish |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=29 August 2010}}</ref> and the most consecutive clean sheets from the start of a league season (6, set during the [[2005–06 FA Premier League|2005–06 season]]).<ref>{{cite news|date=17 September 2005|title=Charlton 0–2 Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/4232354.stm |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=12 November 2007 }}</ref> The club's 21–0 [[Aggregate score|aggregate]] victory over [[UN Käerjéng 97|Jeunesse Hautcharage]] in the [[1971–72 European Cup Winners' Cup|UEFA Cup Winners' Cup in 1971]] remains a record in European competition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/cwc.html#rec|title=Cup Winners' Cup Trivia|publisher=Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|accessdate=21 January 2007}}</ref> Chelsea hold the record for the longest streak of unbeaten matches at home in the English top flight, which lasted 86 matches from 20 March 2004 to 26 October 2008. They secured the record on 12 August 2007, beating the previous record of 63 matches unbeaten set by Liverpool between 1978 and 1980.<ref>{{cite news|date=12 August 2007|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/6931067.stm|title=Chelsea 3–2 Birmingham |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=9 October 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/7674108.stm|title=Chelsea 0–1 Liverpool|publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=26 October 2008 |date=26 October 2008}}</ref> Chelsea's streak of eleven consecutive away league wins, set between 5 April 2008 and 6 December 2008, is also a record for the English top flight.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea in eleven heaven |url=http://www.premierleague.com/page/Magazinedettail/0,,12306~1491763,00.html |publisher=Premier League |date=8 December 2008 |accessdate=18 January 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219192857/http://www.premierleague.com/page/Magazinedettail/0%2C%2C12306~1491763%2C00.html |archivedate=19 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Their £50 million purchase of [[Fernando Torres]] from Liverpool in January 2011 was the [[Progression of British football transfer fee record|record transfer fee paid by a British club]]<ref>{{cite news|date=31 January 2011
|title=Torres makes record move from Liverpool to Chelsea|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/chelsea/9380389.stm |publisher=BBC|accessdate=12 March 2012 }}</ref> until [[Ángel Di María]] signed for Manchester United in August 2014 for £59.7 million.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/12691/9441613/transfer-news-manchester-united-complete-signing-of-angel-di-maria.html
|title=Transfer news: Manchester United sign Angel di Maria from Real Madrid
|work=Sky Sports
}}</ref>

Chelsea, along with Arsenal, were the first club to play with shirt numbers, on 25 August 1928 in their match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea Town]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/TeamUnif/UnifNosNames.html|title=Shirt Numbers
|work=England Football Online|accessdate=1 October 2006 }}</ref> They were the first English side to travel by aeroplane to a domestic away match, when they visited [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 19 April 1957,<ref>{{cite book |last=Glanvill |first=Rick |year=2006 |title=Chelsea FC: The Official Biography |page=96}}</ref> and the first First Division side to play a match on a Sunday, when they faced [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 27 January 1974. On 26 December 1999, Chelsea became the first British side to field an entirely foreign [[starting line-up]] (no British or Irish players) in a Premier League match against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news
 |date=27 December 1999
 |url=http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/chelsea/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer/99/12/26/SOCCER_Southampton_Nightlead.html&TEAMHD=chelsea&DIV=prem&TEAM=CHELSEA&RH=Chelsea&PREV_SEASON=1998
 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603160304/http://www.sportinglife.com/football/premiership/chelsea/reports/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=soccer%2F99%2F12%2F26%2FSOCCER_Southampton_Nightlead.html&TEAMHD=chelsea&DIV=prem&TEAM=CHELSEA&RH=Chelsea&PREV_SEASON=1998
 |archivedate=3 June 2012
 |title=Southampton 1 Chelsea 2
 |work=Sporting Life
 |accessdate=27 January 2007
 |last=Bradley |first=Mark
 |deadurl=yes
 |df=dmy
}}</ref>

In May 2007, Chelsea were the first team to win the FA Cup at the new [[Wembley Stadium]], having also been the last to win it at the old Wembley.<ref>{{cite news|date=20 May 2007|title=Something old, new and Blue|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/blog/2007/may/19/somethingoldnewandblue |work=The Observer|accessdate=14 July 2011|last=Mitchell |first=Kevin}}</ref> They were the first English club to be ranked No. 1 under [[UEFA coefficient|UEFA's five-year coefficient]] system in the 21st century.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.xs4all.nl/~kassiesa/bert/uefa/data/method3/trank2008.html|title=UEFA Team Ranking 2008
|work=UEFA European Cup Football: Results and Qualification|last=Kassies |first=Bert|accessdate=2 June 2008 }}</ref> They were the first team in Premier League history, and the first team in the English top flight since their great rivals Tottenham Hotspur in 1962-63, to score at least 100 goals in a single season, reaching the milestone on the final day of the 2009–10 season.<ref name=Wigan80/> Chelsea are the only London club to win the [[UEFA Champions League]], after beating Bayern Munich in the [[2012 UEFA Champions League Final|2012 final]].<ref name="Chelsea win breaks London duck"/><ref name="Chelsea etch new name on trophy">{{cite news |title=Chelsea etch new name on trophy |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/news/newsid=1798280.html#chelsea+etch+name+trophy |work=Union of European Football Associations |date=19 May 2012 |accessdate=20 May 2012 }}</ref> Upon winning the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]], Chelsea became the first English club to [[European football records|win all four European trophies]] and the only club to hold the Champions League and the Europa League at the same time.<ref>{{cite news|date=15 May 2013|title=Chelsea first team to hold Champions, Europa League titles |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2013/05/chelsea-first-team-to-hold-champions-europa-league-titles/ |work=Vanguard}}</ref>

==Ownership and finances==
[[File:Roman Abramovich 2.jpg|thumb|200px|Chelsea owner [[Roman Abramovich]]]]
Chelsea Football Club were founded by [[Gus Mears]] in 1905. After his death in 1912, his descendants continued to own the club until 1982, when [[Ken Bates]] bought the club from Mears' great-nephew [[Brian Mears]] for £1. Bates bought a controlling stake in the club and floated Chelsea on the [[Alternative Investment Market|AIM]] stock exchange in March 1996.<ref>{{cite web |title=UK Football Clubs on the UK Stock Markets |url=http://www.footballeconomy.com/stats/stats_turnover_09.htm |publisher=Football Economy |accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref> In July 2003, [[Roman Abramovich]] purchased just over 50% of Chelsea Village plc's share capital, including Bates' 29.5% stake, for £30 million and over the following weeks bought out most of the remaining 12,000 shareholders at 35 pence per share, completing a £140 million takeover. Other shareholders at the time of the takeover included the [[Matthew Harding]] estate (21%), [[BSkyB]] (9.9%) and various anonymous offshore trusts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Bates sells off Chelsea to a Russian billionaire |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2406994/Bates-sells-off-Chelsea-to-a-Russian-billionaire.html |work=The Daily Telegraph|date=7 February 2003 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> After passing the 90% share threshold, Abramovich took the club back into private hands, delisting it from the AIM on 22 August 2003. He also took on responsibility for the club's debt of £80 million, quickly paying most of it.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea tycoon to clear club's debt |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/3102819.stm |publisher=BBC|date=28 July 2003 |accessdate=26 June 2012}}</ref>

Thereafter, Abramovich changed the ownership name to Chelsea FC plc, whose ultimate parent company is Fordstam Limited, which is controlled by him.<ref>{{cite web|title=Club Information |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/page/ClubInfo/0,,10268,00.html? |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702215947/http://www.chelseafc.com/page/ClubInfo/0%2C%2C10268%2C00.html |archivedate=2 July 2012 |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=26 June 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> Chelsea are additionally funded by Abramovich via interest free [[soft loan]]s channelled through his holding company Fordstam Limited. The loans stood at £709 million in December 2009, when they were all converted to [[Equity (finance)|equity]] by Abramovich, leaving the club themselves debt free,<ref>{{cite news |title=Roman Abramovich turns £340m of debt into equity as Chelsea loss falls |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/dec/30/roman-abramovich-chelsea-debts-accounts |work=The Guardian|date=30 December 2009 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Statement on Club Finance|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2055740 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140423225239/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2055740 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 April 2014 |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> although the debt remains with Fordstam.<ref>{{cite news |title=Roman Abramovich still owed £726m under complex Chelsea structure |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2010/may/19/roman-abramovich-chelsea-loan-debt |work=The Guardian|date=19 May 2010 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> Since 2008 the club have had no external debt.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea and United debts at record £1.5bn |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/may/20/premierleague.chelsea |work=The Guardian|date=20 May 2008 |accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref>

Chelsea did not turn a profit in the first nine years of Abramovich's ownership, and made record losses of £140m in June 2005.<ref name="first profit">{{cite news |title=Chelsea FC record first Abramovich-era profit|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/20270934 |publisher=BBC|date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=25 February 2015}}</ref> In November 2012, Chelsea announced a profit of £1.4 million for the year ending 30 June 2012, the first time the club had made a profit under Abramovich's ownership.<ref name="first profit"/><ref>{{cite news |title=CHELSEA FC ANNOUNCES ANNUAL PROFIT |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2975285/title/chelsea-fc-announces-annual-profit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111072755/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2975285/title/chelsea-fc-announces-annual-profit |archivedate=11 November 2012 |publisher=Chelsea FC|date=9 November 2012 |accessdate=9 November 2012}}</ref> This was followed by a loss in 2013 and then their highest ever profit of £18.4 million for the year to June 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea FC reports a record £18m in annual profit|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-30045978|accessdate=14 November 2014|publisher=BBC|date=14 November 2014}}</ref>

Chelsea have been described as a global brand; a 2012 report by [[Brand Finance]] ranked Chelsea fifth among football brands and valued the club's brand value at US$398 million – an increase of 27% from the previous year, also valuing them at US$10 million more than the sixth best brand, London rivals Arsenal – and gave the brand a strength rating of AA (very strong).<ref>{{cite web |title=Top 20 most Valuable Football Club Brands |url=http://www.brandfinance.com/images/upload/top_30_european_football_brands_2011_final_website.pdf |publisher=Brand Finance |accessdate=26 June 2012 |date=May 2012 |format=PDF }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Top 30 Football Club Brands |url=http://www.brandfinance.com/images/upload/brandfinance_football_brands_2012.pdf |publisher=Brand Finance |accessdate=4 October 2011 |date=September 2011 |format=PDF }}</ref> In 2016, ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine ranked Chelsea the seventh most valuable football club in the world, at £1.15 billion ($1.66 billion).<ref name="Forbes Valuation">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mikeozanian/2017/06/06/the-worlds-most-valuable-soccer-teams-2017/#54c9255a77ea|title=The World's Most Valuable Soccer Teams 2017|last1=Ozanian|first1=Mike|date=6 June 2017|website=Forbes|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> As of 2016, Chelsea are ranked eighth in the [[Deloitte Football Money League]] with an annual commercial revenue of £322.59 million.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea – Deloitte Football Money League|url=http://www2.deloitte.com/uk/en/pages/sports-business-group/articles/deloitte-football-money-league.html |work=Deloitte |accessdate=21 January 2016 }}</ref>

===Sponsorship===
[[File:Sergio Perez 2012 Canadian GP - Crop.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Sauber|Sauber F1 Team]], an official partner of the club, displaying the Chelsea crest]]
Chelsea's kit has been manufactured by [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] since July 2017. Previously, the kit was manufactured by [[Adidas]], which was originally contracted to supply the club's kit from 2006 to 2018. The partnership was extended in October 2010 in a deal worth £160 million over eight years.<ref>{{cite news |date=22 October 2010 |title=Chelsea manager Carlo Ancelotti puts his faith in elder statesman Didier Drogba
|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/8081823/Chelsea-manager-Carlo-Ancelotti-puts-his-faith-in-elder-statesman-Didier-Drogba.html |work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=27 June 2012}}</ref> This deal was again extended in June 2013 in a deal worth £300 million over another ten years.<ref>{{cite news |date=22 June 2013 |title=Chelsea agree whopping £300m kit deal with sportswear giants adidas |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2346083/Chelsea-agree-record-300m-kit-deal-sportswear-giants-adidas.html |work=Daily Mail |location=London |accessdate=22 June 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=22 June 2013 |title=Chelsea and Adidas Announce Extension of Global Partnership |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3216081/title/chelsea-and-adidas-announce-extension-of-global-partnership |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130624022143/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/3216081/title/chelsea-and-adidas-announce-extension-of-global-partnership |archivedate=24 June 2013 |publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=22 June 2013}}</ref> In May 2016, Adidas announced that by mutual agreement, the kit sponsorship would end six years early on 30 June 2017.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/business-36266181 |title=Adidas ends Chelsea sponsorship six years early |date=11 May 2016 |publisher=BBC |access-date=28 December 2016}}</ref> Chelsea had to pay £40m in compensation to Adidas. In October 2016, Nike was announced as the new kit sponsor, in a deal worth £900m over 15 years, until 2032.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/oct/13/chelsea-new-kit-deal-nike-60m |title=Chelsea confirm kit deal with Nike worth £60m a season until 2032 |date=13 October 2016 |work=The Guardian |access-date=28 December 2016}}</ref> Previously, the kit was manufactured by [[Umbro]] (1975–81), [[Le Coq Sportif]] (1981–86), The Chelsea Collection (1986–87), Umbro (1987–2006), and Adidas (2006–2017).

Chelsea's first shirt sponsor was [[Gulf Air]], agreed during the 1983–84 season. The club were then sponsored by Grange Farms, [[Peter Foster|Bai Lin Tea]] and [[Simod]] before a long-term deal was signed with [[Commodore International]] in 1989; [[Amiga]], an offshoot of Commodore, also appeared on the shirts. Chelsea were subsequently sponsored by [[Coors Brewing Company|Coors]] beer (1994–97), [[Autoglass]] (1997–2001), [[Emirates (airline)|Emirates]] (2001–05), [[Samsung Mobile]] (2005–08) and [[Samsung Group|Samsung]] (2008–15).<ref name=yokohama/><ref>{{cite news |date=2 May 2005 |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/article387503.ece|title=Clubs to cash in on mobile advertising |work=The Times |location=UK |accessdate=21 January 2010 |first=Ashling |last=O'Connor}}</ref> Chelsea's current shirt sponsor is the [[Yokohama Rubber Company]]. Worth £40 million per year, the deal is second in English football to [[Chevrolet]]'s £50 million-per-year sponsorship of Manchester United.<ref name=yokohama>{{cite news|title=Chelsea sign £40m-per-year shirt deal with Japanese tyre company|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31653343|accessdate=27 February 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 February 2015}}</ref>

Following the door-opening of sleeve sponsor in the English League, Chelsea had [[Alliance Tire Company|Alliance Tyres]] as its first sleeve sponsor in the [[2017–18 Chelsea F.C. season|2017–18 season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/alliance-tyres-to-appear-on-2017-18-sleeves.html |title=Alliance Tyres to appear on 2017/18 sleeves |website=chelseafc.com |accessdate=22 July 2017|date=22 July 2017}}</ref> For the [[2018–19 Chelsea F.C. season|2018–19 season]], they have [[Hyundai Motor Company]] as the new sleeve sponsor.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/6/11/chelsea-and-hyundai-begin-new-partnership |title=Chelsea and Hyundai Begin New Partnership |website=chelseafc.com |accessdate=11 June 2018|date=11 June 2018}}</ref>

The club has a variety of other sponsors, which include [[Carabao Energy Drink|Carabao]], [[Delta Air Lines]], [[Beats by Dre]], [[Singha]], [[EA Sports]], [[Rexona]], [[Hublot]], [[Ericsson]], [[William Hill (bookmaker)|William Hill]], [[Levy Restaurants]], [[Wipro]], [[International Beverages Trading|Grand Royal Whisky]], [[Bangkok Bank]], [[Guangzhou R&F F.C.|Guangzhou R&F]], [[Mobinil]], [[IndusInd Bank]], and Ole777.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/the-club/sponsors.html|title=Sponsors and Partners |website=chelseafc.com |publisher=Chelsea FC |accessdate=4 November 2014}}</ref>

==Club personnel==
Chelsea FC plc is the company which owns Chelsea Football Club. The ultimate parent company of Chelsea FC plc is Fordstam Limited and the ultimate controlling party of Fordstam Limited is [[Roman Abramovich]].<ref name="Club Personnel">{{cite web|title=Club Personnel|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/about-chelsea/about-the-club/club-personnel|publisher=Chelsea FC|date=18 July 2018}}</ref>

On 22 October 2014, Chelsea announced that [[Ron Gourlay]], after ten successful years at the club including five as Chief Executive, is leaving Chelsea to pursue new business opportunities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Club statement|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/10/club-statement.html|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=22 October 2014|date=22 October 2014}}</ref> On 27 October 2014, Chelsea announced that [[Christian Purslow]] is joining the club to run global commercial activities and the club do not expect to announce any other senior appointments in the near future having chairman [[Bruce Buck]] and Director [[Marina Granovskaia]] assumed the executive responsibilities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/10/chelsea-statement.html|title=Chelsea Statement|publisher=Chelsea FC|accessdate=27 October 2014|date=27 October 2014}}</ref> [[Guy Laurence]] was appointed as the club's Chief Executive on 11 January 2018, filling the vacancy following the departure of [[Michael Emenalo]].<ref name=GuyLaurence>{{Cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2018/01/new-chief-executive-appointed.html|title=New Chief Executive Appointed|publisher=Chelsea Football Club|date=11 January 2018}}</ref>

Upon winning the [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League]], Chelsea became the fourth club in history to have won the "[[UEFA club competition records and statistics#List of teams to have won the three main European club competitions|European Treble]]" of [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup/UEFA Champions League]], [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|European Cup Winners' Cup/UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]], and [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup/UEFA Europa League]] after [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]] and [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]. [[File:CANDU at Qinshan.jpg|thumb|300 px|[[Qinshan Nuclear Power Plant|Qinshan]] Phase III units 1 and 2, located in [[Zhejiang]] China (30.436° N 120.958° E): Two CANDU 6 reactors, designed by [[Atomic Energy of Canada Limited]] (AECL), owned and operated by the Third Qinshan Nuclear Power Company Limited. Note that the installation is essentially two separate plants, inherent to the CANDU6 design.]]

The '''CANDU''', for '''Canada Deuterium Uranium''', is a Canadian [[pressurized heavy-water reactor]] design used to generate electric power. The acronym refers to its [[deuterium]] oxide ([[heavy water]]) [[neutron moderator|moderator]] and its use of (originally, [[natural uranium|natural]]) [[uranium]] fuel. CANDU reactors were first developed in the late 1950s and 1960s by a partnership between [[Atomic Energy of Canada Limited]] (AECL), the [[Hydro-Electric Power Commission of Ontario]], [[Canadian General Electric]], and other companies.

There have been two major types of CANDU reactors, the original design of around 500 MW<sub>e</sub> that was intended to be used in multi-reactor installations in large plants, and the rationalized '''CANDU 6''' in the 600 MW<sub>e</sub> class that is designed to be used in single stand-alone units or in small multi-unit plants. CANDU 6 units were built in [[Quebec]] and [[New Brunswick]], as well as Pakistan, Argentina, South Korea, Romania, and China. A single example of a non-CANDU 6 design was sold to India. The multi-unit design was used only in [[Ontario]], Canada, and grew in size and power as more units were installed in the province, reaching ~880 MW<sub>e</sub> in the units installed at the [[Darlington Nuclear Generating Station]]. An effort to rationalize the larger units in a fashion similar to CANDU 6 led to the '''CANDU 9'''.

By the early 2000s, sales prospects for the original CANDU designs were dwindling due to the introduction of newer designs from other companies. AECL responded by cancelling CANDU 9 development and moving to the [[Advanced CANDU reactor]] (ACR) design. ACR failed to find any buyers; its last potential sale was for an expansion at Darlington, but this was cancelled in 2009. In October 2011, the Canadian Federal Government licensed the CANDU design to [[Candu Energy Inc.|Candu Energy]] (a wholly owned subsidiary of [[SNC-Lavalin]]), which also acquired the former reactor development and marketing division of AECL at that time. Candu Energy offers support services for existing sites and is completing formerly stalled installations in Romania and Argentina through a partnership with [[China National Nuclear Corporation]]. SNC Lavalin, the successor to AECL, is pursuing new Candu 6 reactor sales in Argentina (Atucha 3), as well as China and Britain. Sales effort for the ACR reactor has ended.

The basic operation of the CANDU design is similar to other nuclear reactors. [[nuclear fission|Fission]] reactions in the reactor core heat pressurized water in a ''primary cooling loop''. A [[heat exchanger]], also known as a [[steam generator (nuclear power)|steam generator]], transfers the heat to a ''secondary cooling loop'', which powers a steam [[turbine]] with an [[electric generator]] attached to it (for a typical [[Rankine cycle|Rankine thermodynamic cycle]]). The exhaust steam from the turbines is then cooled, condensed and returned as feedwater to the steam generator. The final cooling often uses cooling water from a nearby source, such as a lake, river, or ocean. Newer CANDU plants, such as the [[Darlington Nuclear Generating Station]] near [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], use a diffuser to spread the warm outlet water over a larger volume and limit the effects on the environment. {{Citation needed span|text=A [[cooling tower]] can be used, but it reduces efficiency and increases costs considerably.|reason=|date=November 2017}}

Where the CANDU design differs is in the details of the fissile core and the primary cooling loop. [[Natural uranium]] consists of a mix of mostly [[uranium-238]] with small amounts of [[uranium-235]] and trace amounts of other isotopes. Fission in these elements releases high-energy [[neutron]]s, which can cause other U-235 atoms in the fuel to undergo fission as well. This process is much more effective when the neutron energies are much lower than what the reactions release naturally. Most reactors use some form of [[neutron moderator]] to lower the energy of the neutrons, or "[[thermal neutron|thermalize]]" them, which makes the reaction more efficient. The energy lost by the neutrons heats the moderator and is extracted for power.

Most commercial reactor designs use normal water as the moderator. Water absorbs some of the neutrons, enough that it is not possible to keep the reaction going in natural uranium. CANDU replaces this "light" water with [[heavy water]].
Heavy water's extra neutron decreases its ability to absorb excess neutrons, resulting in a better [[neutron economy]]. This allows CANDU to run on unenriched [[natural uranium]], or uranium mixed with a wide variety of other materials such as [[plutonium]] and [[thorium]]. This was a major goal of the CANDU design; by operating on natural uranium the cost of enrichment is removed. This also presents an advantage in [[nuclear proliferation]] terms, as there is no need for enrichment facilities, which might also be used for weapons.
